I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Democratic  Socialist  Republic  of  Sri  Lanka  for  the  Conflict-Affected  Region  Emergency 
Project. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

2. 
For  nearly  three  decades,  Sri  Lanka  has  been  severely  affected  by  an  internal  armed 
conflict.1 While  the  entire  country  suffered  because  of  the  conflict,  Northern  Province  bore  the 
brunt of it. The conflict intensified from February 2007 and government forces gained full control 
of the entire land area by 18 May 2009. The conflict has had a devastating impact on the war-
affected  northern  region  and  its  population;  much  of  the  infrastructure  has  been  damaged  or 
destroyed,  access  to  basic  social  services  has  been  disrupted  and  the  livelihood  of  the 
population severely affected. The incidence of poverty in Northern Province is estimated at 37% 
(compared  with  15%  for  the  country  as  a  whole),  which  is  probably  an  underestimate  of  the 
actual poverty. The province contributed a mere 2.9% of the country's gross domestic product 
over 2005–2007, despite having 14% of the country's land mass, 40% of the coastal belt, and 
6%  of  the  population.  The  prolonged  conflict  has  caused  immense  human  suffering,  with 
civilians getting internally displaced from their homes, thus creating an estimated 277,000 new 
internally displaced persons (IDPs).2 With progress on de-mining of the affected area, the IDPs 
are  returning  to  their  original  areas  of  residence. 3  As  of  early  March  2010,  according  to 
government  estimates,  about  85,000–90,000  IDPs  were  still  to  be  resettled  in  their  original 
places of residence.  
 
The  immediate  need  in  the  post-conflict  phase  is  to  resettle  the  IDPs  in  their  original 
3. 
area  of  residence,  provide  them  with  relief,  reestablish  basic  services,  revive  the  people’s 
livelihood,  and  restore  the  most  urgently  needed  damaged  infrastructure.  On  1  July  2009,  the 
government  launched  a  180-day  plan  for  resettlement  of  IDPs  and  to  enable  them  to  restart 
their  livelihoods. 4
   The  180-day  plan  includes  the  restoration  of  public  administration,  social 
services,  and  community  and  social  infrastructure  to  meet  the  most  critical  basic  needs  of  the 
IDPs. To support the 180-day program, the government requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and other development partners to (i) assist with restarting stalled projects in the conflict-
affected  areas,  (ii)  provide  additional  assistance  through  surplus  funds  and  loan  savings  from

  2 

the existing portfolio, and (iii) provide additional emergency financing. 5 A presidential task force 
was appointed in July 2009 with the task of formulating a strategic framework for revitalizing the 
economy  of  the  northern  region  to  ensure  livelihood  recovery  and  a  sustained  reduction  in 
poverty. A needs assessment was conducted by the government and a medium-term strategy 
was formulated. The strategy focuses on (i) resettlement of displaced persons and protection of 
their  fundamental  rights;  (ii)  revitalization  of  basic  livelihood  through  revival  and  expansion  of 
productive  sectors;  (iii)  accelerated  development  of  infrastructure  in  roads,  electricity,  ports, 
transport,  water  supply  and  sanitation,  and  housing;  (iv)  improvement  in  the  rural  economy 
through  technological  transformation;  (v)  sustainable  extraction  of  marine  resources;  (vi) 
improvement in knowledge, skills, and talent of youth; (vii) institutional reform for upgrading the 
quality  and  performance  of  public  service;  and  (viii)  encouraging  private  investment  through 
establishment of industrial estates. The total investment required for the program during 2010–
2012 is estimated at $2.68 billion.6 
 
4. 
To  meet  some  of  the  most  urgent  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  priorities,  the 
government has requested ADB for emergency loan assistance for the Conflict-Affected Region 
Emergency  Project.  ADB  fielded  three  missions  to  the  conflict-affected  regions  in  Northern 
Province,  Eastern  Province,  and  the  adjoining  areas  of  North  Central  Province.  Extensive 
discussions were held with district officials and representatives of the provincial councils, central 
line  ministries,  Ministry  of  Nation  Building  and  Estate  Infrastructure  Development,  and  the 
Ministry  of  Finance  and  Planning.  Due  to  security  concerns  in  the  post-conflict  period  and  the 
gradual  release  and  return  of  IDPs,  the  processing  of  the  project  was  delayed.  Based  on 
discussions  with  the  government,  preliminary  processing  began  in  November  2009.  Although 
the formal request by the government for the emergency loan was made on 19 January 2010, 
the actual processing took more than 12 weeks, exceeding the requirements of the Disaster and 
Emergency Assistance Policy.7 
 
5. 
The objective of the project is to significantly expand and strengthen the reconstruction 
of urgently needed essential infrastructure and administrative services, assist in meeting basic 
human  needs  and  create  livelihood  and  sustainable  employment  opportunities  in  the  conflict-
affected  areas  by  supporting  the  recovery  of  the  region's  economy.  The  project  will  focus 
primarily  on  the  war-affected  Northern  Province,  and  some  components  will  focus  on  Eastern 
Province and some border villages in North Central Province, which were also affected by the 
conflict. 
 
6. 
The  project  is  part  of  the  wider  assistance  being  provided  by  ADB  and  other 
development  partners  to  the  returning  IDPs  in  the  conflict-affected  areas. 8  The  Australian 
Agency  for  International  Development  has  provided  livelihood  grants  to  returning  IDPs 
channeled through ADB and World Bank projects. India is supplying relief materials for shelter, 
agriculture,  medical  supplies,  and  temporary  hospital  facilities,  and  is  supporting  vocational 
training  center  rehabilitation  and  the  reconstruction  of  railways.  The  Japan  International 
Cooperation  Agency  (JICA)  is  assisting  in  rehabilitation  of  minor  irrigation  tanks,  agriculture,

3

rural and provincial roads and the power sector.9 The People's Republic of China has provided 
humanitarian assistance and construction equipment, and is also providing substantial support 
for  the  rehabilitation  of  roads.  The  United  Nations  and  affiliated  agencies  and  a  number  of 
bilateral development partners have been providing humanitarian, rehabilitation, and livelihood 
assistance.10 The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) is implementing the Access 
to  Justice  Project.  The  project  provides  legal  aid  and  documentation  to  IDPs  and  conflict-
affected  persons,  training  of  justice  sector  officials,  alternate  dispute  resolution  services,  and 
legal assistance to vulnerable groups. The United States Agency for International Development 
is supporting the Public–Private Alliance Project and a program to reintegrate ex-combatants in 
Northern  and  Eastern  provinces.  Immediate  rehabilitation  needs  and  creation  of  livelihood  are 
also  being  met  through  the  World  Bank's  Emergency  Northern  Recovery  Project,  approved  in 
December 2009, and through its ongoing projects in housing, community livelihood, the health 
and education sectors, and provincial roads.  
 
7. 
For the last several years ADB has engaged in development work in the conflict-affected 
areas. Following cessation of hostilities in May 2009, ADB continued to address the immediate 
rehabilitation needs of IDPs through its ongoing projects in the north and the east of the country. 
The North  East Community Restoration and Development  (NECORD)  II project is focusing on 
repairing damaged schools, hospitals, and administrative buildings, providing tractors to farmers 
to  restart  agriculture,  and  providing  livelihood  grants  to  30,000  IDP  families.11 The  Conflict-
Affected Areas Rehabilitation Project is expediting the ongoing road works in the area; a motor 
launch has been provided to connect outlying islands with the Jaffna Peninsula.12 Installation of 
the  medium-sized  and  rural  electrification  schemes,  especially  in  Kilinochchi  and  Mullaitivu 
districts,  has  been  restarted.  Loan  savings  of  nearly  $5  million  from  the  Secondary  Education 
and Modernization Project II13 and Education for Knowledge Society Project14 are being used to 
fund rehabilitation of nearly 500 schools in Northern Province for urgent repairs to the buildings 
and  rehabilitation  of  computer  and  science  labs.  Under  the  Aquatic  Resources  Development 
and  Quality  Improvement  Project,  $410,000  has  been  allocated  to  restart  livelihoods  through 
development  of  inland  fisheries  in  reservoirs  in  Northern  Province. 15 Rehabilitation  activities 
have  been  further  strengthened  with  provision  of  supplementary  finance  of  $12.8  million  from 
loan  savings  and  cancellation  to  the  NECORD  II  project.  In  addition,  further  loan  savings  and 
cancellations of around $13 million is expected to be used to provide a supplementary loan to

B. 

Impact and Outcomes 

The  project's  main  impact  will  be  to  reduce  poverty  and  help  meet  basic  needs  by 
8. 
improving  the  living  conditions  and  sustainable  livelihood  prospects  of  the  war-affected 
population in Northern Province, Eastern Province, and some adjoining villages in North Central 
Province. Rehabilitation and reconstruction of essential infrastructure by this and other projects 
will  make  private  investment  viable  and  result  in  accelerated  economic  growth  and  therefore 
increase  employment  opportunities.  Along  with  improved  service  delivery  and  rapid  economic 
growth,  the  incidence  of  poverty  in  the  region  is  expected  to  fall  from  37%  in  2010  to  15%  in 
2020. Significant employment opportunities will also be created by the project itself. 
 
9. 
Several  key  outcomes  will  emerge  from  the  project.  Reestablishing  connectivity  by 
repairing damaged roads in the municipal areas, provincial roads, and some national roads will 
improve access to basic services and enable marketing and trade to resume, one of the keys to 
the  reestablishment  of  livelihood.  It  will  also  reduce  travel  times  by  about  30%  and  reduce 
vehicle  operating  costs  by  20%.  With  better  connectivity,  private  sector  investment  will  be 
attracted to the region. 
 
Basic utilities such as drinking water and electricity are grossly inadequate in the region 
10. 
due  to  a  long  period  of  underinvestment  because  of  the  prevailing  conflict  situation  and  poor 
maintenance  of  existing  structures.  The  proportion  of  the  population  covered  by  piped  water 
varies between 2% and 20% in different districts of the north. The project will provide improved 
access  to  power  to  about  750,000  people  in  Northern  Province,  and  about  35,000  people  will 
gain access to safe drinking water in Northern and Eastern provinces. Sustainable and gainful 
means of employment requires that small and medium-sized irrigation works are rehabilitated so 
that agricultural activities can be revived. By investing in such irrigation schemes, the project will 
enable 6,000 families to restart cultivation on about 6,500 hectares of land. The rebuilding and 
rehabilitation of three vocational training institutes, and providing them with related facilities, will 
help  to  meet  the  critical  skills  shortages,  generating  nonfarm  employment  for  about  1,200 
people  per  annum.  Prolonged  conflict  has  also  severely  affected  the  functioning  and 
effectiveness of the governance structure, including public administration and judicial services. 
The  administrative  structure  has  been  weakened  due  to  the  war  and  damaged  buildings. 
Repairing  them  will  allow  effective  service  delivery  to  be  restored.  Prolonged  conflict  has  also 
hampered the effective functioning of institutions responsible for civil and judicial administration 
in Northern Province. Having a fully operational governance system is essential to support early 
recovery  efforts  and  sustain  rehabilitation  and  rebuilding  initiatives.  This  component  of  the 
project will provide about 1 million people with access to essential legal services.

The outputs of the project are summarized below while the project component analysis 

1. 

Component A: Reestablishing Connectivity 

12. 
This component will rehabilitate (i) 65 kilometers (km) of national roads (B category) in 
Northern  Province,  (ii)  100  km  of  provincial  roads  in  Kilinochchi,  Mannar,  Mullaitivu  and 
Vavuniya districts,19 and (iii) 100 km of municipal and urban council roads in Northern Province 
and rural roads in the adjoining villages of North Central Province. Rehabilitation of these roads 
will increase connectivity for the returning IDPs,  facilitating the provision of basic services and 
livelihood  recovery  and  encourage  increased  investment.  Local  and  provincial  council  roads 
serve communities located away from the centers of economic activity which have high poverty 
incidence and lack economic opportunities. This component will focus on some critical sections 
of the road network that will complement the work supported by other development partners as 
well as future planned work, including work by ADB.  
 

2. 

Component B: Restoring Utilities 

13.  Most of the electricity infrastructure was destroyed during the conflict, and the remaining 
infrastructure  has  deteriorated  due  to  lack  of  maintenance.  The  project  will  support  the 
reconstruction of the Chunnakam grid station and the Kilinochchi–Chunnakam transmission line. 
This  will  provide  the  essential  link  to  Jaffna,  as  JICA  is  supporting  the  reconstruction  of  the 
damaged transmission line from Vavuniya to Kilinochchi.  
 
14. 
the  water  supply  schemes  at 
Echchalampattu  in  Trincomalee  district  and  Point  Pedro  in  Jaffna  district.  These  schemes  are 
designed  to  meet  the  needs  of  resettled  IDPs.  The  population  relies  mainly  on  dug  and  tube 
wells  for  their  water  needs;  this  water  is  not  always  fit  for  consumption,  nor  the  wells  easy  to 
use.  Moreover,  development  activities  that  will  take  place  in  the  area  in  the  near  future  will 
create greater demand for water supply facilities.

3. 

Component C: Improving Basic Social Services 

15. 
This  component  will  restore  some  essential  basic  social  services  and  livelihood 
opportunities  of  the  population  by  (i) restoring  about  10  small  and  medium-sized  irrigation 
schemes as agriculture is the main source of livelihood;20 (ii) rebuilding 10 administrative offices 
and  providing  related  facilities;  and  (iii) rehabilitating  and  reconstructing  district  vocational 
training centers in Kilinochchi, Mannar, and Mullaitivu. 
 
16. 
Agriculture  is  the  key  economic  activity  for  a  majority  of  the  population  in  Northern 
Province. The province is in the dry zone, and rains from the northwest monsoon are limited and 
irregular. The cropping intensity in the province remains low as a majority of tanks and canals 
are dilapidated due to limited or no investment since the early 1980s. ADB is also exploring the

17.  Most  of  the  district  and  divisional  administration  buildings  in  Northern  Province  have 
been  damaged;  in  Kilinochchi  and  Mullaitivu,  almost  all  district  and  divisional  secretariats  and 
local authority buildings have been destroyed. However, some offices are being repaired under 
the 180-day program. These institutions have also lost most of the office furniture, equipment, 
machinery, and vehicles. 
 
18. 
There  are  16  technical  education  and  vocational  training  centers  in  Northern  Province, 
some  of  which  have  been  closed  due  to  the  conflict.  The  youth  in  the  province  have  not 
acquired new skills; hence their employment prospects are low. Repair and refurbishment of the 
vocational  training  centers  is  essential  for  the  development  of  the  war-affected  region  in  the 
short-to-medium term.   
 

4. 

Component D: Legal Infrastructure 

19. 
This component will rehabilitate courthouses and related facilities in up to nine strategic 
locations  in  Northern  Province.21 The  prolonged  conflict  has  prevented  institutions  responsible 
for  civil  and  judicial  administration  in  Northern  Province  from  functioning  effectively.  With  the 
end  of  the  conflict,  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  of  the  judicial  infrastructure  is  urgently 
needed, as its absence is negatively impacting the perceived personal and communal security 
of the war-affected communities and IDPs. Judicial officers have already been appointed and at 
present most of the court proceedings take place under extremely difficult conditions in partially 
damaged buildings.  
 
20. 
The project's support for reconstruction of physical legal infrastructure will be provided in 
coordination  with  UNDP,  which  is  implementing  its  Access  to  Justice  Project.  A  letter  of 
understanding was signed with UNDP in March 2010 so that the two activities complement each 
other to ensure comprehensive development of the justice sector.

F. 

Project Selection Criteria 

30. 
In  choosing  the  project  components,  discussions  were  held  with  provincial,  local,  and 
national  government  officials  and  administrative  staff,  most  of  whom  were  directly  responsible 
for delivering essential services to IDPs. With the process of resettlement of IDPs still ongoing 
and  de-mining  activities  also  in  progress  in  many  areas,  the  IDPs  (the  intended  beneficiaries) 
could  not  be  consulted.  During  implementation,  discussions  will  be  held  with  the  IDPs, 
community-based  organizations,  nongovernment  organizations,  user  groups  (e.g.,  farmer 
organizations),  and  local  political  leaders  to  ensure  ownership  and  maximize  project  benefits. 
This will be particularly relevant to components relating to local, municipal, and provincial roads; 
irrigation works; administrative structures; and legal facilities.  
 
Projects  will  be  selected  to  ensure  equitable  distribution  of  rehabilitation  works  across 
31. 
the  entire  Northern  Province,  taking  into  account  geographic  and  sector  balance  along  with 
ethnic  composition.  Project  selection  will  incorporate  conflict-sensitivity  guidelines. 25  Where 
necessary for project selection, people in target villages will be consulted in a gender-sensitive 
way,  and  also  encouraged  to  participate  in  construction  work  as  wage  labor.  During  project 
implementation,  contractors  will  ensure  that  there  is  wage  parity  for  male  and  female  labor. 
Lessons  from  emergency  loans  such  as  the  NECORD,26 Conflict-Affected  Area  Rehabilitation 
Project,27 and  Tsunami-Affected  Area  Rehabilitation  Project28 have  been  incorporated  in  the 
design.  The  government  and  ADB  have  agreed  on  the  following  project  selection  and  criteria: 
(i) de-mining  is  completed  and  safe  access  is  assured  by  the  government  to  the  IDPs  and 
project  staff;  (ii)  the  targeted  beneficiaries  have  either  returned  to  the  project  area  or  the 
government  provides  a  plan  to  resettle  the  IDPs  in  the  area;  (iii)  there  is  balance  of  activities 
between districts and communities; and (iv) projects can be completed within the loan period.

Auditor  General  for  a  separate  audit  opinion  on  compliance  with  financial  covenants  in  its 
projects. Project procurement will be subject to ADB's Procurement Guidelines.

basis to deal with bribery and corruption. Use of open competitive bidding, transparency in the 
selection  of  projects,  and  the  oversight  role  of  ADB  will  ensure  integrity  in  procurement  and 
implementation  activities.  The  executing  agency  will  maintain  a  project  website  that  will  be

Safeguards 

D. 

38. 
This project is not expected to require land acquisition or resettlement, as reconstruction 
will occur at original sites or along existing corridors. However, since exact locations of projects 
have not been identified at this stage, resettlement impacts of a specific project of the loan will 
only  be  known  during  project  implementation,  and  as  a  result  the  resettlement  plans  will  be 
prepared, if necessary, in accordance with the resettlement framework in the course of project 
implementation. No project component or project with potential involuntary resettlement impacts 
will  be  implemented  until  an  appropriate  resettlement  planning  instrument  to  address  such 
impacts  is  formulated,  approved  by  ADB  and  respective  authorities  in  the  government,  and 
implemented  following  the  guidelines  given  in  the  resettlement  framework.32 The  resettlement 
framework sets out the policy and procedures for screening project components and projects to 
identify resettlement impacts, if any, and to guide the executing and implementing agencies on 
how to prepare resettlement plans to address such impacts adequately and to implement them 
effectively.  
 
39. 
From  an  environmental  standpoint,  the  project  is  classified  category  B  as  it  is  unlikely 
that  any  proposed  projects  will  lead  to  any  adverse  irreversible  impacts.  Initial  environmental 
examinations will be conducted for the transmission line and grid substation, roads, and water 
supply  components.  Contracts  for  these  components  will  be  awarded  only  after  approval  of 
initial  environmental  examinations  and  environmental  management  plans  by  ADB  and  the 
government  (if  required),  and  the  plans  will  form  part  of  the  contract  documents.  All  other 
projects  will  follow  environmental  assessment  procedures  stipulated  in  the  environmental 
assessment framework. The framework has been developed to ensure compliance with ADB's 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).33

40.  Major  risks  are  (i)  tensions  arising  from  beneficiaries  due  to  perceived  inequities  in

and  labor  in  project  civil  works,  (iii)  delay  in  clearing  land  mines  leading  to  delay  in  project 
implementation,  (iv)  inadequate  institutional  capacity  among  national  and  provincial  agencies 
and 
local  nongovernment  organizations  and  community-based  organizations,  and  (v) 
inadequate  coordination  among  development  partners.  The  government  and  ADB  are  actively 
engaged  in  implementing  measures  to  mitigate  these  risks.  The  project  design  incorporates 
features to mitigate some of these risks, such as adopting the conflict-sensitivity guidelines and 
encouraging the use of local labor through the bidding documents. Training will also be provided 
to  local  contractors  on  ADB's  policies  and  procedures.  The  Government,  in  collaboration  with
